Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story: I glanced out my window and saw the trash bins lined up along the curb, only half-full. Mrs. Patel, my elderly neighbor, always appreciated it when I waited until the last minute to roll out my bin so she could add her bags—her arthritis made it hard for her to manage on her own. I knew she’d be counting on me to leave space for her, just as I always did. But as I reached for my keys to step outside, my radio crackled to life. “Unit 4, possible cardiac arrest, respond immediately.” My heart jumped. Every second mattered in my job as an ambulance driver; someone’s life could depend on how fast I got behind the wheel. I hesitated, torn between the urge to help Mrs. Patel and the duty to rush to the ambulance. The expectation to be a good neighbor tugged at me, but the weight of my responsibility as an ambulance driver pressed even harder. I stood frozen, keys in hand, wrestling with the impossible choice between being there for my neighbor and saving a stranger’s life.
